title: 107_s610
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Police Gun Buyback Assistance Act" and includes findings and purpose. Congress finds that decommissioned firearms previously used by law enforcement agencies have been involved in various crimes, including shootings at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles and near a playground in Chicago. Additionally, firearms stolen during shipment from the Miami-Dade Police Department have been traced to crimes in Chicago. In the past 9 years, decommissioned firearms once used by law enforcement agencies have been involved in over 3,000 crimes, including 293 homicides, 301 assaults, and 279 drug-related crimes. Many State and local law enforcement departments also resell firearms confiscated from crimes, including assault weapons that were in circulation before restrictions were imposed. The Act aims to reduce the number of firearms on the streets by helping law enforcement agencies stop the practice of reselling confiscated firearms involved in crimes, particularly assault weapons. Some states and cities have chosen to destroy decommissioned firearms instead. The Act aims to reduce firearms on the streets by assisting law enforcement in preventing the transfer of decommissioned firearms to individuals. The Act aims to reduce firearms on the streets by assisting law enforcement in preventing the transfer of decommissioned firearms to individuals. SEC. 3. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Attorney General may provide grants to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms, as long as they have a policy in place to prevent the transfer of decommissioned firearms to individuals. The local government must have a policy to prevent transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals and must destroy these firearms. Exceptions allow transfer to law enforcement agencies. Grants received under this Act can only be used to purchase new firearms. To apply for a grant under this Act, the chief executive of a State or unit of local government must submit an application to the Attorney General with required information. Regulations for the grant application process are outlined in the Act. The Attorney General must create regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment for grant applications under this Act. The regulations will outline the required information and criteria for States and local governments applying for grants. Additionally, reporting requirements are specified in the Act. SEC. 6. REPORTING.

A State or unit of local government must report to the Attorney General within 2 years of receiving funds under this Act on its implementation. The report should include budget assurances for law enforcement agencies to purchase firearms without transferring decommissioned ones.

SEC. 7. DEFINITION. In this Act, a "decommissioned firearm" refers to a firearm no longer used by law enforcement or involved in a crime. "Firearm" and "person" have standard legal definitions. Authorization of appropriations for $10,000,000 annually from 2001 to 2005 is provided in this Act.
